pull.title: test: add coverage for `-bantime`
pull.body: This PR adds test coverage for `-bantime`. This flag sets the time in seconds how long the IP is banned (in the case you don't explicitly set `bantime` when using `setban`).

events.body:

### Conflicts
Reviewers, this pull request conflicts with the following ones:

* [#26863](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/26863) (test: merge banning test from p2p_disconnect_ban to rpc_setban by brunoerg)

If you consider this pull request important, please also help to review the conflicting pull requests. Ideally, start with the one that should be merged first.

Concept ACK

I was [testing ChatGPT](https://twitter.com/1440000bytes/status/1598247456462221312) to see if it can review pull requests and it suggested 4 improvements that make sense:

Thanks, @1440000bytes for your review. Interesting experiment using an AI, however, I believe it doesn't deal so well with some specific stuff from our framework. E.g. It doesn't know 100% what our `assert` functions do (perhaps the reason it suggested a text message on the assertion).

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -70,6 +71,11 @@ def run_test(self):
         assert not self.is_banned(node, tor_addr)
         assert not self.is_banned(node, ip_addr)
 
+        self.log.info("Test -bantime")
+        self.restart_node(1, ["-bantime=1234"])
+        self.nodes[1].setban("127.0.0.1", "add")
+        banned = self.nodes[1].listbanned()[0]
+        assert_equal(banned['ban_duration'], 1234)
comments.body:
The assert_equal function should be called with the expected value as the first argument and the actual value as the second argument.

```suggestion
        assert_equal(1234, banned['ban_duration'])
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -70,6 +71,11 @@ def run_test(self):
         assert not self.is_banned(node, tor_addr)
         assert not self.is_banned(node, ip_addr)
 
+        self.log.info("Test -bantime")
+        self.restart_node(1, ["-bantime=1234"])
+        self.nodes[1].setban("127.0.0.1", "add")
+        banned = self.nodes[1].listbanned()[0]
+        assert_equal(banned['ban_duration'], 1234)
comments.body:
It is generally a good idea to include a descriptive error message in the call to assert_equal so that it is clear what the error is if the assertion fails.

```suggestion
        assert_equal(1234, banned['ban_duration'], "ban_duration is not equal to 1234")
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -70,6 +71,11 @@ def run_test(self):
         assert not self.is_banned(node, tor_addr)
         assert not self.is_banned(node, ip_addr)
 
+        self.log.info("Test -bantime")
+        self.restart_node(1, ["-bantime=1234"])
+        self.nodes[1].setban("127.0.0.1", "add")
+        banned = self.nodes[1].listbanned()[0]
comments.body: The code should check the return value of self.nodes[1].listbanned() to make sure it is not empty before trying to access the first element. If the list is empty, then the ban on 127.0.0.1 was not successful, and the code should fail the test.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -70,6 +71,11 @@ def run_test(self):
         assert not self.is_banned(node, tor_addr)
         assert not self.is_banned(node, ip_addr)
 
+        self.log.info("Test -bantime")
+        self.restart_node(1, ["-bantime=1234"])
+        self.nodes[1].setban("127.0.0.1", "add")
+        banned = self.nodes[1].listbanned()[0]
comments.body:
It would be more readable if the code assigned the return value of self.nodes[1].listbanned() to a variable, and then accessed the first element of the list using that variable.

```suggestion
        banned_list = self.nodes[1].listbanned()
        assert len(banned_list) > 0, "Failed to ban 127.0.0.1"
        banned = banned_list[0]
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -70,6 +71,11 @@ def run_test(self):
         assert not self.is_banned(node, tor_addr)
         assert not self.is_banned(node, ip_addr)
 
+        self.log.info("Test -bantime")
+        self.restart_node(1, ["-bantime=1234"])
+        self.nodes[1].setban("127.0.0.1", "add")
+        banned = self.nodes[1].listbanned()[0]
comments.body:
tAck but how about adding another coverage to test the ban remaining time after the bantime elapsed.

`time.sleep(secs)`
`banned = self.nodes[1].listbanned()[0]`
`assert_equal(banned["time_remaining"],0) `

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -70,6 +71,11 @@ def run_test(self):
         assert not self.is_banned(node, tor_addr)
         assert not self.is_banned(node, ip_addr)
 
+        self.log.info("Test -bantime")
+        self.restart_node(1, ["-bantime=1234"])
+        self.nodes[1].setban("127.0.0.1", "add")
+        banned = self.nodes[1].listbanned()[0]
+        assert_equal(banned['ban_duration'], 1234)
comments.body: Pretty sure this will lead to a race when the rpc is dispatched after a one second sleep?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -70,6 +71,11 @@ def run_test(self):
         assert not self.is_banned(node, tor_addr)
         assert not self.is_banned(node, ip_addr)
 
+        self.log.info("Test -bantime")
+        self.restart_node(1, ["-bantime=1234"])
+        self.nodes[1].setban("127.0.0.1", "add")
+        banned = self.nodes[1].listbanned()[0]
+        assert_equal(banned['ban_duration'], 1234)
comments.body: Where is/why the one second sleep?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -70,6 +71,11 @@ def run_test(self):
         assert not self.is_banned(node, tor_addr)
         assert not self.is_banned(node, ip_addr)
 
+        self.log.info("Test -bantime")
+        self.restart_node(1, ["-bantime=1234"])
+        self.nodes[1].setban("127.0.0.1", "add")
+        banned = self.nodes[1].listbanned()[0]
+        assert_equal(banned['ban_duration'], 1234)
comments.body:
Ah sorry. You are checking the ban_duration, not time_remaining. So this is fine. For reference, the output with the CPU put to sleep for a second looked like:

```json
{
"address": "127.0.0.1/32", 
"ban_created": 1682845373, 
"banned_until": 1682846607, 
"ban_duration": 1234, 
"time_remaining": 1233
}
